substeps.message: DB Values returned for the query are: As no development has been reported for some time, this program is assumed to be discontinued.Mpex Pharmaceuticals was developing  MP-601205, an aerosol formulation of an established  bacterial efflux pump inhibitor (EPI), for the potential enhancement of antibiotic efficacy in bacterial lung  infections in  patients with cystic fibrosis, hospital-acquired pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), for the potential treatment of Gram-negative bacterial infection [553966], [553483], [773218]. In August 2004, Mpex filed an IND for a phase Ib trial, which was expected to begin in September 2004 [553483]. By March 2005, phase Ia studies, in combination with ciprofloxacin,  had been completed and further phase Ib and IIa studies were being planned [594324].,

Values returned in the response are: As no development has been reported for some time, this program is assumed to be discontinued.Mpex Pharmaceuticals was developing  MP-601205, an aerosol formulation of an established  bacterial efflux pump inhibitor (EPI), for the potential enhancement of antibiotic efficacy in bacterial lung  infections in  patients with cystic fibrosis, hospital-acquired pneumonia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), for the potential treatment of Gram-negative bacterial infection [553966], [553483], [773218]. In August 2004, Mpex filed an IND for a phase Ib trial, which was expected to begin in September 2004 [553483]. By March 2005, phase Ia studies, in combination with ciprofloxacin,  had been completed and further phase Ib and IIa studies were being planned [594324].,

substeps.message: DB Values returned for the query are: LEO Pharma has developed and launched   LEO-80185 (LEO-90105; Xamiol;  Daivobet; Dovobet; Taclonex), a once-daily topical formulation of the vitamin D analog  calcipotriol (0.005%) and the corticosteroid betamethasone dipropionate (0.064%). The product is indicated (as Taclonex) in the US as an ointment formulation for the topical treatment of psoriasis vulgaris in adults, and as a topical gel suspension for the treatment of plaque psoriasis of the scalp and body in patients 18 years and older and for the treatment of plaque psoriasis of the scalp in patients age 12 to 17 years [1998148], [2101283]. In Europe, the product is indicated  as an ointment formulation (as Daivobet and Dovobet) for the treatment of adults with plaque psoriasis where it is possible to use a topical medicine, and as a gel for the treatment of psoriasis on the scalp or mild to moderate plaque psoriasis on other parts of the body  [2101132]. In Japan, the product is indicated (as Dovobet Gel) for the treatment of plaque psoriasis   [2006182]. The ointment version of the product was first launched in Denmark in April 2001 [552777]. During 2002, launches also took place in several further European markets  [554886]. In April 2006, the ointment was launched for plaque psoriasis in adults in the US by former licensee Warner Chilcott, as Taclonex [659472]. In September 2014, the ointment was launched (as Dovobet) in Japan by licensee Kyowa Hakko Kirin  [1593169]. In November 2008, LEO launched a topical gel formulation, as Xamiol, in Europe for scalp psoriasis [959008], [959080];  at that time, the US licensee, Warner Chilcott, was also reported to be engaged in sales work for the formulation in the US (as Taclonex Scalp) [959008].     In October 2012, the topical suspension formulation (presumed to be the gel version) was additionally approved by the FDA for body plaque psoriasis in adults  [1335220], [1598559]. In September 2014, the gel formulation was approved by the FDA for the treatment of    plaque psoriasis of the scalp in pediatric patients from aged 12 years [1598559]. In June 2018, the gel formulation   (Dovobet Gel) was launched in Japan [2041757]. In July 2013, Leo Pharma launched a 120-g packet size of Taclonex topical gel suspension for plaque psoriasis [1456379]. In 2014, a gel applicator was approved in the US and Europe to facilitate application in difficult-to-reach areas [1671640]; the applicator was launched in Europe 2015, and at that time was expected to be launched in the US in 2016 [1778391].LEO also markets Enstilar, a foam formulation of Taclonex.,

Values returned in the response are: LEO Pharma has developed and launched   LEO-80185 (LEO-90105; Xamiol;  Daivobet; Dovobet; Taclonex), a once-daily topical formulation of the vitamin D analog  calcipotriol (0.005%) and the corticosteroid betamethasone dipropionate (0.064%). The product is indicated (as Taclonex) in the US as an ointment formulation for the topical treatment of psoriasis vulgaris in adults, and as a topical gel suspension for the treatment of plaque psoriasis of the scalp and body in patients 18 years and older and for the treatment of plaque psoriasis of the scalp in patients age 12 to 17 years [1998148], [2101283]. In Europe, the product is indicated  as an ointment formulation (as Daivobet and Dovobet) for the treatment of adults with plaque psoriasis where it is possible to use a topical medicine, and as a gel for the treatment of psoriasis on the scalp or mild to moderate plaque psoriasis on other parts of the body  [2101132]. In Japan, the product is indicated (as Dovobet Gel) for the treatment of plaque psoriasis   [2006182]. The ointment version of the product was first launched in Denmark in April 2001 [552777]. During 2002, launches also took place in several further European markets  [554886]. In April 2006, the ointment was launched for plaque psoriasis in adults in the US by former licensee Warner Chilcott, as Taclonex [659472]. In September 2014, the ointment was launched (as Dovobet) in Japan by licensee Kyowa Hakko Kirin  [1593169]. In November 2008, LEO launched a topical gel formulation, as Xamiol, in Europe for scalp psoriasis [959008], [959080];  at that time, the US licensee, Warner Chilcott, was also reported to be engaged in sales work for the formulation in the US (as Taclonex Scalp) [959008].     In October 2012, the topical suspension formulation (presumed to be the gel version) was additionally approved by the FDA for body plaque psoriasis in adults  [1335220], [1598559]. In September 2014, the gel formulation was approved by the FDA for the treatment of    plaque psoriasis of the scalp in pediatric patients from aged 12 years [1598559]. In June 2018, the gel formulation   (Dovobet Gel) was launched in Japan [2041757]. In July 2013, Leo Pharma launched a 120-g packet size of Taclonex topical gel suspension for plaque psoriasis [1456379]. In 2014, a gel applicator was approved in the US and Europe to facilitate application in difficult-to-reach areas [1671640]; the applicator was launched in Europe 2015, and at that time was expected to be launched in the US in 2016 [1778391].LEO also markets Enstilar, a foam formulation of Taclonex.,
